{{short description|2014 American 3D computer-animated superhero-comedy film}} {{Use American English|date=March 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Big Hero 6 | image = Big Hero 6 (film) poster.jpg | alt = A big white round inflatable health robot assistant. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = {{Plainlist| *[[Don Hall (filmmaker)|Don Hall]] *[[Chris Williams (director)|Chris Williams]] }} | producer = {{Plainlist | *[[Kristina Reed]] *[[Roy Conli]]}} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| *[[Jordan Roberts (writer)|Jordan Roberts]] *[[Dan Gerson]] *Robert L. Baird }} | based on = {{based on|''[[Big Hero 6 (comics)|Big Hero 6]]''|[[Man of Action Studios|Man of Action]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| *[[Ryan Potter]] *[[Scott Adsit]] *[[Daniel Henney]] *[[T.J. Miller]] *[[Jamie Chung]] *[[Damon Wayans Jr.]] *[[Genesis Rodriguez]] *[[James Cromwell]] *[[Maya Rudolph]] *[[Alan Tudyk]] }} | music = [[Henry Jackman]] | cinematography = {{Plainlist| *Rob Dressel *Adolph Lusinsky }} | editing = Tim Mertens | studio = {{Plainlist| *[[Walt Disney Pictures]] *[[Walt Disney Animation Studios]] }} | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2014|10|23|[[Tokyo International Film Festival|Tokyo International
Film Festival]]|2014|11|07|United States}} | runtime = 102 minutes{{cite web|url=http://www.ofrb.gov.on.ca/ofrb/OfrbWelcomeAction.do?detailParameter=2000118255|title=Ontario Film Review Board: Big Hero 6|publisher=Ontario Film Review Board|accessdate=November 6, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Big Hero 6 – Synopsis|url=http://disneystudiosawards.com/awards/big-hero-6|publisher=Disney Studio Awards|accessdate=December 27, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227173200/http://disneystudiosawards.com/awards/big-hero-6|archivedate=December 27, 2014|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $165 million{{cite web|date=November 4, 2014|author=Brent Lang|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/box-office-interstellar-big-hero-6-eye-record-breaking-weekend-1201347238|title=Box Office: 'Interstellar,' 'Big Hero 6' Eye Record-Breaking Weekend|work=Variety|accessdate=November 5, 2014}} | gross = $657.8 million }} '''''Big Hero 6''''' is a 2014 American [[3D film|3D]] [[Computer animation|computer-animated]] [[superhero film]] produced by [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]] and released by [[Walt Disney Pictures]]. Loosely based on the [[Big Hero 6 (comics)|superhero team of the same name]] by [[Marvel Comics]], the film is the 54th [[List of Walt Disney Animation Studios films|Disney animated feature film]].{{cite web|first=Matt|last=McDaniel|url=https://www.yahoo.com/movies/big-hero-6-exclusive-poster-reveal-walt-disney-86413335667.html|title=Disney Throws Out the Marvel Rulebook for 'Big Hero 6'|publisher=Yahoo! Movies|date=May 21, 2014|accessdate=July 8, 2014}} Directed by [[Don Hall (filmmaker)|Don Hall]] and [[Chris Williams (director)|Chris Williams]], the film tells the story of [[Hiro Takachiho#In other media|Hiro Hamada]], a young robotics prodigy who forms a superhero team to combat a masked villain. The film features the voices of [[Scott Adsit]], [[Ryan Potter]], [[Daniel Henney]], [[T.J. Miller]], [[Jamie Chung]], [[Damon Wayans Jr.]], [[Genesis Rodriguez]], [[Alan Tudyk]], [[James Cromwell]], and [[Maya Rudolph]]. ''Big Hero 6'' is the first Disney animated film to feature Marvel Comics characters, [[Marvel Entertainment|whose parent company]] was acquired by [[The Walt Disney Company]] in 2009.{{cite news|last=Truitt|first=Brian|title=Disney animates Marvel characters for 'Big Hero 6'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2013/05/09/disney-marvel-comics-big-hero-6-animation/2147293|accessdate=May 9, 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=May 9, 2013}} Walt Disney Animation Studios created new software technology to produce the film's animated visuals.{{cite news|last1=Roper|first1=Caitlin|title=Big Hero 6 Proves It: Pixar's Gurus Have Brought the Magic Back to Disney Animation|url=https://www.wired.com/2014/10/big-hero-6|publisher=Wired.com|date=October 21, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Hall|first1=Gina|title=How John Lasseter's Pixar Culture Led to 'Big Hero 6' Breakthrough for Disney|url=http://www.thewrap.com/how-john-lasseters-pixar-culture-led-to-big-hero-6-breakthrough-for-disney|accessdate=November 13, 2014|publisher=The Wrap|date=November 7, 2014}} ''Big Hero 6'' premiered at the 27th [[Tokyo International Film Festival]] on October 23, 2014, and at the [[Abu Dhabi Film Festival]] on October 31; it was theatrically released in the [[Disney Digital 3-D]] and [[RealD 3D]] formats in the United States on November 7, 2014. The film was met with both critical and commercial success, grossing over $657.8 million worldwide and becoming the [[List of animated feature films of 2014|highest-grossing animated film of 2014]].{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/big-hero-6-no-1-animated-movie-worldwide-2014-1201392779/|title='Big Hero 6': No. 1 Animated Movie Worldwide 2014|first=Kinsey |last=Lowe |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 13, 2015|accessdate=March 14, 2015}} It won the [[Academy Award for Best Animated Feature]] and the [[Kids' Choice Awards|Kids' Choice Award]] for Favorite Animated Movie. It also received nominations for the [[Annie Award for Best Animated Feature]], the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film]], and the [[BAFTA Award for Best Animated Film]]. ''Big Hero 6'' was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray|Blu-ray Disc]] on February 24, 2015. A [[Big Hero 6: The Series|television series]], which continues the story of the film, debuted on November 20, 2017 on [[Disney Channel]] and [[Disney XD]]. {{TOC limit|3}} ==Plot== Hiro Hamada is a 14-year-old robotics genius living in the futuristic city of San Fransokyo who spends much of his free time participating in illegal [[Robot combat|robot fights]]. To redirect Hiro, his older brother Tadashi takes him to the research lab at the San Fransokyo Institute of Technology, where Hiro meets Tadashi's friends, GoGo, Wasabi, Honey Lemon, and Fred. Hiro also meets Professor Robert Callaghan, the head of the university's robotics program. Amazed, Hiro decides to apply to the university. To enroll, he signs up for the school's science fair and presents his project: [[microbots]], swarms of tiny robots that can link together in any arrangement imaginable using a neurocranial transmitter. At the fair, Hiro declines an offer from Alistair Krei, CEO of Krei Tech, to market the microbots, and Callaghan accepts him into the school. At the end of the day, a fire breaks out among the exhibits and Tadashi rushes in to save Callaghan, the only person left inside. The building explodes moments later, killing Tadashi. Weeks later, a depressed Hiro, in mourning for Callaghan's and Tadashi's death, inadvertently activates Baymax, the [[Soft robotics|inflatable]] healthcare robot that Tadashi created; the two find Hiro's only remaining microbot and follow it to an abandoned warehouse. There they discover that someone has been mass-producing the microbots, and are attacked by a man wearing a [[Kabuki]] mask who is controlling them. After they escape, Hiro equips Baymax with armor and a battle chip containing various [[karate]] moves, and they track the masked man to the docks. GoGo, Wasabi, Honey Lemon, and Fred arrive, responding to a call from Baymax, and the masked man chases the group. The six escape to Fred's mansion, where they decide to form a high-tech superhero team to combat the villain. The group tracks the masked man, whom they suspect to be Krei, to an abandoned Krei Tech laboratory which was used for [[teleportation]] research until a test pilot was lost in an accident. The masked man attacks, but the group subdues him and knocks off his mask – revealing him to be Callaghan, who had stolen and used Hiro's microbots to shield himself from the explosion, leaving Tadashi to die. Enraged, Hiro removes Baymax's healthcare chip, leaving only the battle chip, and orders him to kill Callaghan. Honey reinstalls the healthcare chip at the last second, preventing Baymax from carrying out the kill order. Callaghan escapes, and Hiro leaves with Baymax, intent on avenging Tadashi. Back home, Hiro tries to remove the healthcare chip again, but Baymax stops him and states that vengeance is not what Tadashi would have wanted. To calm him down, Baymax shows Hiro videos of Tadashi running numerous tests during Baymax's development as a demonstration of Tadashi's benevolence and legacy. Hiro remorsefully apologizes to his friends, who reassure him they will catch Callaghan the right way. Video footage from the laboratory accident reveals that the lost test pilot was Callaghan's daughter Abigail, and that Callaghan is seeking revenge on Krei. Callaghan interrupts Krei at a public event and attempts to destroy his headquarters using Krei's teleportation portal. After a lengthy battle, the team deprives Callaghan of his microbots and the mask, saving Krei, but the portal remains active. Baymax detects Abigail inside, alive but in hyper-sleep, and leaps into the portal with Hiro to rescue her. They find Abigail's pod, but on the way back out, Baymax is struck by debris, damaging his armor and disabling his thrusters. With no other option Baymax activates his armor's rocket fist, and asks Hiro to say he is satisfied with his care, to the shock of Hiro, but Baymax convinces him to do it, saying he will always be with him. Hiro agrees, and Baymax fires his rocket fist, propelling Hiro and Abigail back through the portal before it closes. Callaghan is arrested while Abigail is taken to the hospital. Some time later, Hiro discovers Baymax's health care chip clenched in the rocket fist. He rebuilds Baymax's body, and the six friends continue their exploits throughout the city. During the end credits, a series of newspaper headlines reveals that the university has awarded Hiro a grant and dedicated a building in Tadashi's honor, and that the team has continued protecting the city. In a [[post-credits scene]], Fred discovers a hidden cache of superhero equipment in his family mansion. His father, a retired superhero, returns from vacation and says, "We have a lot to talk about." ==Cast== {{Further|List of Disney's Big Hero 6 characters}} *[[Ryan Potter]] as [[Hiro Hamada|Hiro]], a 14-year-old robotics prodigy. Speaking of the character, co-director [[Don Hall (filmmaker)|Don Hall]] said "Hiro is transitioning from boy to man, it's a tough time for a kid and some teenagers develop that inevitable snarkiness and jaded attitude. Luckily Ryan is a very likeable kid. So no matter what he did, he was able to take the edge off the character in a way that made him authentic, but appealing".{{cite web|last=Truitt|first=Brian|title=Meet the saviors of San Fransokyo in 'Big Hero 6'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/07/13/big-hero-6-character-reveal-exclusive/12535005|work=USA Today|accessdate=July 13, 2014|date=July 13, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Hiro|url=https://thismoment-a.akamaihd.net/other/1410708503-2030.pdf|publisher=xprizechallenge.org|accessdate=September 24, 2014}} *[[Scott Adsit]] as [[Baymax (Disney)|Baymax]], an inflatable robot built by Tadashi as a medical assistant. Hall said, "Baymax views the world from one perspective – he just wants to help people, he sees Hiro as his patient". Producer [[Roy Conli]] said "The fact that his character is a [[robot]] limits how you can emote, but Scott was hilarious. He took those boundaries and was able to shape the language in a way that makes you feel Baymax's emotion and sense of humor. Scott was able to relay just how much Baymax cares".{{cite web|title=Baymax|url=https://thismoment-a.akamaihd.net/other/1410708438-2030.pdf|publisher=xprizechallenge.org|accessdate=September 24, 2014}} *[[Daniel Henney]] as [[Tadashi Hamada|Tadashi]], Hiro's older brother and Baymax's creator. On Hiro and Tadashi's relationship, Conli said "We really wanted them to be brothers first. Tadashi is a smart mentor. He very subtly introduces Hiro to his friends and what they do at San Fransokyo Tech. Once Hiro sees Wasabi, Honey, GoGo, and Fred in action, he realizes that there's a much bigger world out there that really interests him". *[[T.J. Miller]] as [[Fred (Disney)|Fred]], a comic-book fan and [[slacker]] who is also a team mascot at San Fransokyo Institute of Technology. Speaking of Miller, Williams said "He's a real student of comedy. There are a lot of layers to his performance, so Fred ended up becoming a richer character than anyone expected", both literally and metaphorically.{{cite web|last=Stradling|first=Morgan|title=Comedian TJ Miller is First Voice Actor Announced for Disney's 'Big Hero 6' – He's Voicing Fred!|url=http://www.rotoscopers.com/2014/03/27/comedian-tj-miller-is-first-voice-actor-announced-for-disneys-big-hero-6|publisher=Rotoscopers|accessdate=March 28, 2014|date=March 27, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Fred|url=https://thismoment-a.akamaihd.net/other/1410708464-2030.pdf|publisher=xprizechallenge.org|accessdate=September 24, 2014}} *[[Jamie Chung]] as [[Go Go Tomago (Disney)|Go Go]], a tough, athletic student who specializes in electromagnetics. Hall said "She's definitely a woman of few words. We looked at bicycle messengers as inspiration for her character".{{cite web|title=Jamie Chung Next to Not Be Announced for 'Big Hero 6'|url=http://www.stitchkingdom.com/disney-jamie-chung-announced-big-hero-6-70660|publisher=Stitch Kingdom|accessdate=April 28, 2014|date=April 28, 2014}}{{cite web|last=Sneider|first=Jeff|title=Disney's 'Big Hero 6' Adds Maya Rudolph to Top-Secret Voice Cast (Exclusive)|url=http://www.thewrap.com/disneys-big-hero-6-adds-maya-rudolph-top-secret-voice-cast-exclusive|publisher=The Wrap|accessdate=April 28, 2014|date=April 28, 2014}}{{cite web|title=GoGo|url=https://thismoment-a.akamaihd.net/other/1410708483-2030.pdf|publisher=xprizechallenge.org|accessdate=September 24, 2014}} *[[Damon Wayans Jr.]] as [[Wasabi (Disney)|Wasabi]], a smart, slightly neurotic youth who specializes in lasers. On the character, co-director [[Chris Williams (director)|Chris Williams]] said "He's actually the most conservative, cautious—he {{sic}} the most normal among a group of brazen characters. So he really grounds the movie in the second act and becomes, in a way, the voice of the audience and points out that what they're doing is crazy".{{cite web|title=Wasabi|url=https://thismoment-a.akamaihd.net/other/1410708542-2030.pdf|publisher=xprizechallenge.org|accessdate=September 24, 2014}} *[[Genesis Rodriguez]] as [[Honey Lemon (Disney)|Honey Lemon]], a chemistry enthusiast at San Fransokyo Institute of Technology. Williams said "She's a glass-is-half-full kind of person. But she has this mad-scientist quality with a twinkle in her eye – there's more to Honey than it seems".{{cite web|title=Honey Lemon|url=https://thismoment-a.akamaihd.net/other/1410708521-2030.pdf|publisher=xprizechallenge.org|accessdate=September 24, 2014}} *[[James Cromwell]] as Robert Callaghan, the head of a robotics program at San Fransokyo Institute of Technology who becomes an extremely powerful masked supervillain, who plans revenge on Krei.{{cite web|last1=Yamato|first1=Jen|title=Maya Rudolph, James Cromwell, More Join Disney's Marvel Animation 'Big Hero 6'|url=http://deadline.com/2014/07/disney-big-hero-6-voice-cast-804122|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=September 5, 2014|date=July 14, 2014}} According to film merchandising, this supervillain alter ego is named "Yokai".{{cite web|title=Baymax and the Big Hero 6 are Ready For Action|url=http://blogs.disney.com/insider/2014/07/14/big-hero-6-cast-announcement/|website=Disney Insider|publisher=Walt Disney Company|accessdate=February 28, 2015}} *[[Alan Tudyk]] as Alistair Krei, a pioneer entrepreneur, tech guru, and the CEO of Krei Tech and is always on the hunt for the next big thing. *[[Maya Rudolph]] as Cass, Hiro and Tadashi's aunt and guardian.{{cite web|title=Meet the characters in Big Hero 6, Disney's upcoming action-packed comedy-adventure.|url=http://blogs.disney.com/oh-my-disney/2014/07/13/six-reasons-we-cant-wait-to-see-big-hero-6/#go-go-tomago|publisher=Oh My Disney – Disney|accessdate=July 13, 2014|date=July 13, 2014}} *[[Katie Lowes]] as Abigail, the daughter of Professor Callaghan and a test pilot for Krei Tech.{{cite web|title=Big Hero 6: Press Kit|url=http://www.wdsmediafile.com/media/bigHero6/writen-material/bigHero6544eac07033e9.pdf|publisher=The Walt Disney Studios|accessdate=March 1, 2015}} *[[Daniel Gerson]] as Desk Sergeant, the desk sergeant for the San Fransokyo Police Department. *[[Paul Briggs (animator)|Paul Briggs]] as Yama, a notorious gangster who seeks revenge after Hiro defeats his robot in a clandestine robot fight with illegal betting. *[[David Shaughnessy]] as Heathcliff, Fred's family butler. *[[Billy Bush]] as Newscaster{{cite web|last=Patten|first=Dominic|title='Big Hero 6′ Wins Oscar For Animated Film|url=http://deadline.com/2015/02/big-hero-6-wins-oscar-best-animated-film-2015-academy-award-winner-1201379190/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=March 11, 2015|date=February 22, 2015}} *[[Stan Lee]] as Fred's dad, has a brief scene at the end of the credits.{{cite web|last1=Donn|first1=Emily|title=Big Hero 6 Stan Lee Cameo Revealed|url=http://comicbook.com/2014/11/07/big-hero-6-stan-lee-cameo-revealed|publisher=ComicBook.com|accessdate=November 7, 2014|date=November 7, 2014}} ==Production== After [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]]'s acquisition of [[Marvel Entertainment]] in 2009, CEO [[Bob Iger]] encouraged the company's divisions to explore Marvel's properties for adaptation concepts.{{cite news|last=Keegan|first=Rebecca|title=Disney is reanimated with 'Frozen,' 'Big Hero 6'|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-disney-big-hero-6-frozen-20130508-dto,0,4722556.htmlstory|accessdate=May 9, 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=May 9, 2013}} By deliberately picking an obscure title, it would give them the freedom to come up with their own version.{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/movies/big-hero-6/25567/disneymarvel-announce-new-major-animated-film-big-hero-6|title=Disney/Marvel announce new major animated film, Big Hero 6|work=Den of Geek|accessdate=October 23, 2014}} While directing ''[[Winnie the Pooh (2011 film)|Winnie the Pooh]]'', director [[Don Hall (filmmaker)|Don Hall]] was scrolling through a Marvel database when he stumbled upon ''Big Hero 6'', a comic he had never heard of before. "I just liked the title," he said. He pitched the concept to [[John Lasseter]] in 2011, as one of five ideas{{cite news|last1=Tilley|first1=Steve|title='Big Hero 6': Disney brings little-known Marvel stars to big screen|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2014/10/30/big-hero-6-disney-brings-little-known-marvel-stars-to-big-screen|accessdate=November 9, 2014|work=Toronto Sun|publisher=Canoe Sun Media|date=November 2, 2014}} for possible productions for Walt Disney Animation Studios, and this particular idea "struck a chord" with Lasseter, Hall, and [[Chris Williams (director)|Chris Williams]].{{cite news|last=Keegan|first=Rebecca|title=Exclusive: Disney Animation announces first Marvel movie, 'Big Hero 6'|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/movies/exclusive-disney-animation-announces-first-marvel-movie-big-hero-6|accessdate=May 9, 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=May 9, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/08/would-disney-make-films-in-the-marvel-universe.html|title=Disney Hasn't Talked to Marvel About Setting Films in Its Cinematic Universe|author=Kyle Buchanan|date=August 28, 2014|work=Vulture|accessdate=October 23, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/entertainment/movie-guide/Hero+banks+huggable+robot+draw+audiences/10350057/story.html|title=Big Hero 6 banks on a huggable robot to draw in audiences|work=Vancouver Sun}} In June 2012, Disney confirmed that Walt Disney Animation Studios was adapting Marvel Comics' series and that the film had been commissioned into early stages of development.{{cite news|last=Breznican|first=Anthony|title=Disney Animation teams up with Marvel for 'Big Hero 6' – BREAKING|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2012/06/29/disney-animation-confirms-plans-for-marvels-big-hero-6-breaking|accessdate=May 9, 2013|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=June 29, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Nicholson|first=Max|title=Confirmed: Disney Animating Marvel's Big Hero 6|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/06/30/marvels-big-hero-6-hitting-the-big-screen|publisher=IGN|accessdate=May 9, 2013|date=June 29, 2012}} Because they wanted the concept to feel new and fresh, head of story [[Paul Briggs (animator)|Paul Briggs]] (who also voices Yama in the film{{cite web|last=Guzman|first=René|title=S.A. artist drew on personal experience for 'Big Hero 6' scene|url=http://www.expressnews.com/lifestyle/article/S-A-artist-drew-on-personal-experience-for-Big-5884086.php#/0|work=expressnews.com|accessdate=December 12, 2014|date=November 11, 2014}}) only read a few issues of the comic, while screenwriter Robert Baird admitted he had not read the comic at all.{{cite news|last1=Sims|first1=Andrew|title=Hypable goes behind 'Big Hero 6': How Disney Animation is taking on their first Marvel property|url=http://www.hypable.com/2014/09/03/big-hero-6-san-fransokyo-disney-marvel-adaptation|accessdate=November 9, 2014|work=Hypable|date=September 3, 2014}} ''Big Hero 6'' was produced solely by Walt Disney Animation Studios,{{cite news|last=Gregg|first=Kilday|title=Disney Animation's Andrew Millstein on a 'Frozen' Sequel and the Studio's Next Marvel Collaboration (Q&A)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/frozen-sequel-disney-animations-andrew-679137|accessdate=March 7, 2014|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=February 12, 2014}} although several members of Marvel's creative team were involved in the film's production including [[Joe Quesada]], Marvel's [[chief creative officer]], and [[Jeph Loeb]], head of [[Marvel Television]].{{cite web|last=Strauss|first=Bob|date=November 6, 2014|url=http://www.dailynews.com/arts-and-entertainment/20141106/marvel-meets-disney-animation-in-big-hero-6|title=Marvel meets Disney Animation in 'Big Hero 6'|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|location=New York}}{{cite news|last=Lang|first=Brent|title=Marvel, Disney Partner on Animated Release: 'Big Hero 6' (Video)|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/article/marvel-disney-set-first-animated-release-big-hero-6-video-90441/|accessdate=May 9, 2013|newspaper=The Wrap|date=May 9, 2013}} According to an interview with Axel Alonso by [[Comic Book Resources|CBR]],{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=55190|title=Axel-In-Charge: The Mixed Message of Manara's 'Spider-Woman' Variant, Reason For No 'Big Hero 6' Plans|publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]]}} Marvel did not have any plans to publish a tie-in comic.{{cite web|url=http://www.bleedingcool.com/2014/09/02/marvel-agreed-with-disney-not-to-put-out-big-hero-6-comics/|title=Marvel Agreed With Disney Not To Put Out Big Hero 6 Comics|author=Rich Johnston|work=Bleeding Cool Comic Book, Movie, TV News}} Disney planned to reprint the Marvel version of ''Big Hero 6'' themselves, but reportedly Marvel disagreed. They eventually came to agreement that [[Yen Press]] would publish the Japanese [[manga]] version of ''Big Hero 6'' for Disney.{{cite web|url=http://www.bleedingcool.com/2014/09/04/that-disneymarvel-bust-up-over-big-hero-6|title=That Disney/Marvel Bust Up Over Big Hero 6|work=Bleeding Cool Comic Book, Movie, TV News|accessdate=October 23, 2014}} Conversely, Lasseter dismissed the idea of a rift between the two companies, and producer [[Roy Conli]] stated that Marvel allowed Disney "complete freedom in structuring the story".{{cite web|last=Feinberg|first=Scott|title=John Lasseter Dismisses Notion of Rift With Marvel Over 'Big Hero 6'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/john-lasseter-dismisses-notion-rift-728424|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=September 24, 2014|date=August 27, 2014}}{{cite web|title=We are Chris Williams, Don Hall, Roy Conli, and Paul Briggs of BIG HERO 6 – AUA!|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/movies/comments/2iuxn3/we_are_chris_williams_don_hall_roy_conli_and_paul|publisher=Reddit|accessdate=October 10, 2014|date=October 10, 2014}} Disney Animation Studio President Andrew Millstein stated: "''Hero'' is one example of what we've learned over the years and our embracing some of the [[Pixar]] DNA."{{cite web|last=Lealos|first=Shawn S.|title=Big Hero 6 Sequel: What Will it Take to Get Made?|url=http://renegadecinema.com/36093/big-hero-6-sequel-what-will-it-take-to-get-made|work=Renegade Cinema|accessdate=February 18, 2015|date=February 18, 2015}} Regarding the film's story, Quesada stated, "The relationship between Hiro and his robot has a very Disney flavor to it ... but it's combined with these Marvel heroic arcs." The production team decided early on not to connect the film to the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] and instead set the film in a stand-alone universe.{{cite web|last=Film|first=Total|url=http://www.totalfilm.com/news/big-hero-6-director-confirms-the-avengers-won-t-make-cameos|title=Big Hero 6 director confirms the Avengers won't make cameos|publisher=TotalFilm.com|date=July 4, 2014|accessdate=July 8, 2014}} [[File:Inflatable Robotic Arm.jpg|thumb|An inflatable vinyl robotic arm that helped inspire Baymax's design, from the researchers in the new field of [[soft robotics]] at [[Carnegie Mellon University]]'s [[Robotics Institute]].]] With respect to the design of Baymax, Hall mentioned in an interview, "I wanted a robot that we had never seen before and something to be wholly original. That's a tough thing to do, we've got a lot of robots in pop culture, everything from [[Terminator (character)|The Terminator]] to [[WALL-E#Cast and characters|WALL-E]] to [[C-3PO]] on down the line and not to mention [[Japanese robots]], I won't go into that. So I wanted to do something original." Even if they did not yet know what the robot should look like, artist Lisa Keene came up with the idea that it should be a huggable robot.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-10-31/-big-hero-6-turns-godzilla-into-lovable-disney-robot.html|title='Big Hero 6' Turns Godzilla into Lovable Disney Robot|author=Christopher Palmeri|date=October 31, 2014|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=November 5, 2014}} Other sources of inspiration cited by the team include Japanese [[anime]], such as [[Hayao Miyazaki]] films (including ''[[Spirited Away]]'' and ''[[The Wind Rises]]'') and ''[[Pokémon]]'', as well as [[Shogun Warriors (toys)|Shogun Warriors]] toys.{{cite news |title=How anime inspired Disney’s ‘Big Hero 6’ |url=https://nypost.com/2014/11/01/will-disneys-japanese-anime-big-hero-6-get-lost-in-translation/ |work=[[New York Post]] |date=November 1, 2014}} [[Mecha]] designer Shigeto Koyama, who previously did design work for [[mecha anime]] such as ''[[Gunbuster 2]]'', ''[[Eureka Seven]]'', ''[[Gurren Lagann]]'', and ''[[Rebuild of Evangelion]]'', worked on the concept design for Baymax.{{cite news |title=Interview: Shigeto Koyama Talks About Baymax, GAINAX And Kill la Kill |url=https://www.superadrianme.com/event-2/interview-shigeto-koyama-baymax/ |work=superadrianme.com |date=17 September 2015}}{{cite news |title=Designer Reveals "Big Hero 6" Anime Connection |url=https://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2014/10/24/designer-reveals-big-hero-6-anime-connection |work=[[Crunchyroll]] |date=October 24, 2014}} Early on in the development process, Hall and the design team took a research trip to [[Carnegie Mellon University]]'s [[Robotics Institute]], where they met a team of [[DARPA]]-funded{{cite news|last1=Aitoro|first1=Jill R.|title=DARPA goes Disney thanks to 'Big Hero 6'|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/blog/fedbiz_daily/2014/11/darpa-goes-disney-thanks-to-big-hero-6.html|accessdate=February 10, 2015|work=Washington Business Journal|publisher=American City Business Journals|date=November 19, 2014}} researchers who were pioneering the new field of '[[soft robotics]]' using inflatable vinyl,{{cite web|url=http://www.cmu.edu/homepage/health/2011/winter/soft-bots.shtml|title=Easy Does It|publisher=Carnegie Mellon University (CMU)|accessdate=October 23, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ubergizmo.com/2011/01/inflatable-robot-arm-wont-break-any-bones|title=Inflatable robot arm won't break any bones|author=Edwin Kee|work=Ubergizmo|accessdate=October 23, 2014}} which ultimately inspired Baymax's inflatable, vinyl, truly huggable design.{{cite web|url=http://geekdad.com/2014/10/technology-big-hero-6|title=The Technology of Big Hero 6|work=GeekDad|accessdate=October 23, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~cga/bighero6|title=Big Hero 6|publisher=Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science|accessdate=November 5, 2014}} Hall stated that "I met a researcher who was working on soft robots. ... It was an inflatable vinyl arm and the practical app would be in the healthcare industry as a nurse or doctor's assistant. He had me at vinyl. This particular researcher went into this long pitch but the minute he showed me that inflatable arm, I knew we had our huggable robot."{{cite web|url=http://news.moviefone.com/2014/07/15/big-hero-6-directors-new-trailer|title=The 'Big Hero 6' Directors Reveal the Story Behind the Wild New Trailer (EXCLUSIVE)|date=July 15, 2014|work=The Moviefone Blog|accessdate=October 23, 2014}} Hall stated that the technology "will have potential probably in the medical industry in the future, making robots that are very pliable and gentle and not going to hurt people when they pick them up." Hall mentioned that achieving a unique look for the mechanical armor took some time and "just trying to get something that felt like the personality of the character". Co-director Williams stated, "A big part of the design challenge is when he puts on the armor you want to feel that he's a very powerful intimidating presence ... at the same time, design-wise he has to relate to the really adorable simple vinyl robot underneath."{{cite web|last=McDaniel|first=Matt|title=First Teaser for Marvel and Disney's 'Big Hero 6': Meet Their 'Huggable' Robot|url=https://www.yahoo.com/movies/big-hero-6-exclusive-teaser-trailer-walt-disney-86509088837.html|publisher=Yahoo! Movies|accessdate=June 1, 2014|date=May 22, 2014}} Baymax's face design was inspired by a copper ''[[suzu]]'' bell that Hall noticed while at a [[Shinto]] shrine.{{cite news|last1=Collin |first1=Robbie |title=Why Big Hero 6 is Disney's most loveable creation in years |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/11190289/Why-Big-Hero-6-is-Disneys-most-loveable-creation-in-years.html |accessdate=November 1, 2014 |work=The Telegraph |date=November 1, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TlfeiTj0?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/11190289/Why-Big-Hero-6-is-Disneys-most-loveable-creation-in-years.html |archivedate=November 1, 2014 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} According to Conli, Lasseter initially disliked Baymax's description (while low on battery power) of Hiro's cat as a "hairy baby", but Williams kept the line in anyway, and at the film's first test screening, Lasseter admitted that Williams was correct.{{cite news|last1=Bodey|first1=Michael|title=Big Hero 6: another animation marvel from Disney|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/big-hero-6-another-animation-marvel-from-disney/story-e6frg8n6-1227169452274|accessdate=January 1, 2015|work=The Australian|publisher=News Corp Australia|date=December 30, 2014}} According to Williams, Baymax was originally going to be introduced rather late in the film, but then story artist John Ripa conceived of a way for Baymax to meet Hiro much earlier.{{cite journal|last1=Lark|first1=Max|last2=Draskovic|first2=Marina|last3=Solomon|first3=Charles|title=It's a Matter of Trust: At Walt Disney Animation Studios, The 'Story Trust,' A Peer-to-Peer Feedback System, Has Taken Storytelling—And Disney Animation—To New Creative Heights|journal=Disney twenty-three|date=Spring 2016|volume=8|issue=1|pages=18–21|publisher=Walt Disney Company|location=Burbank|issn=2162-5492|oclc=698366817}} The entire film became much stronger by establishing the relationship between Hiro and Baymax early on, but the filmmakers ended up having to reconstruct "a fair amount of the first act" in order to make that idea work. About ninety animators worked on the film at one point or another; some worked on the project for as long as two years.{{cite news|last1=Stuart|first1=Sophia|title=Behind the Scenes of Disney's Tech-Centric 'Big Hero 6'|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2471740,00.asp|accessdate=November 9, 2014|work=PC Magazine|publisher=[[Ziff Davis, LLC]]|date=November 6, 2014}} In terms of the film's animation style and settings, the film combines [[Eastern world]] culture (predominantly [[Culture of Japan|Japanese]]) with [[Western world]] culture (predominantly [[Culture of California|California]]).{{cite web|last=Krupa|first=Daniel|title=Disney Animation Announces First Marvel Movie, Big Hero 6|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/05/09/disney-animation-announces-first-marvel-movie-big-hero-6|publisher=IGN|accessdate=May 9, 2013}} In May 2013, Disney released concept art and rendered footage of San Fransokyo from the film.{{cite news|last=Acuna|first=Kirsten|title=Gorgeous Concept Art For Disney's First Animated Marvel Film|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/big-hero-6-disneys-first-animated-marvel-film-2013-5|accessdate=May 9, 2013|newspaper=Business Insider|date=May 9, 2013}} San Fransokyo, the futuristic mashup of San Francisco and Tokyo, was described by Hall as "an alternate version of San Francisco. Most of the technology is advanced, but much of it feels retro … Where Hiro lives, it feels like [[Haight-Ashbury|the Haight]]. I love the [[Painted ladies]]. We gave them a Japanese makeover; we put a cafe on the bottom of one. They live above a coffee shop." According to production designer Paul Felix, "The topography is exaggerated because what we do is caricature, I think the hills are 1½ times exaggerated. I don't think you could really walk up them ... When you get to the downtown area, that's when you get the most Tokyo-fied, that pure, layered, dense kind of feeling of the commercial district there. When you get out of there, it becomes more San Francisco with the Japanese aesthetic. … (It's a bit like) ''[[Blade Runner]]'', but contained to a few square blocks. You see the skyscrapers contrasted with the hills."{{cite web|last=Ordoña|first=Michael|title=If S.F., Tokyo merged with retro twist, you'd get 'Big Hero 6'|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/movies/article/If-S-F-Tokyo-merged-with-retro-twist-you-d-5709497.php|work=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=August 27, 2014|date=August 24, 2014}} The reason why Disney wanted to merge Tokyo (which is where the comic book version takes place) with San Francisco was partly because San Francisco had not been used by Marvel before, partly because of all the city's iconic aspects, and partly because they felt its aesthetics would blend well with Tokyo. The filmmakers' idea was that San Fransokyo is based on an alternative history in which San Francisco was largely rebuilt by Japanese immigrants in the aftermath of the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake|1906 earthquake]], although this premise is never stated in the film.{{cite news|last1=Keegan|first1=Rebecca|title=San Fransokyo architects built a new world for Disney's Big Hero 6|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/movies/san-fransokyo-architects-built-a-new-world-for-disneys-big-hero-6/|accessdate=December 10, 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Tribune Publishing Company|date=October 24, 2014}} To create San Fransokyo as a detailed digital simulation of an entire city, Disney purchased the actual [[Tax assessment|assessor]] data for the entire city and county of San Francisco. The final city contains over 83,000 buildings and 100,000 vehicles. A software program called Denizen was used to create over 700 distinctive characters that populate the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.iamrogue.com/news/interviews/item/11968-iar-goes-behind-the-scenes-of-big-hero-6-disneys-take-on-a-marvel-superhero-team.html|title=IAR Screens 'Big Hero 6' Footage and Goes Behind the Scenes of Disney's Next|accessdate=October 23, 2014}} Another one named Bonzai was responsible for the creation of the city's 250,000 trees,{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcocreate.com/3037877/the-monster-supercomputing-achievement-that-lights-up-disneys-big-hero-6|title=The Monster Supercomputing Achievement That Lights Up Disney's 'Big Hero 6'|work=Co.Create}} while a new rendering system called Hyperion offered new illumination possibilities, like light shining through a translucent object (e.g. Baymax's vinyl covering).{{cite news|last1=Ford|first1=Steven|title=Disney creates new digital animation process for 'Big Hero 6'|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/travel/attractions/the-daily-disney/os-disney-creates-new-digital-animation-process-for-big-hero-6-20141020-story.html|accessdate=October 30, 2014|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=October 20, 2014}} [[Pixar]]'s [[RenderMan (software)|RenderMan]] was considered as a "Plan B" for the film's [[Rendering (computer graphics)|rendering]], if Hyperion was not able to meet production deadlines. Development on Hyperion started in 2011 and was based upon research into multi-bounce complex [[global illumination]] originally conducted at [[Disney Research]] in [[Zürich]]. Disney, in turn, had to assemble a new super-computing cluster just to handle Hyperion's immense processing demands, which consists of over 2,300 Linux workstations distributed across four data centers (three in [[Los Angeles]] and one in San Francisco). Each workstation, {{as of|2014|lc=y}}, included a pair of 2.4 GHz Intel Xeon processors, 256 GB of memory, and a pair of 300 GB [[solid-state drive]]s configured as a [[Standard RAID levels|RAID Level 0 array]] (i.e., to operate as a single 600 GB drive). This was all backed by a central storage system with a capacity of five [[petabyte]]s, which holds all digital assets as well as archival copies of all 54 Disney Animation films. The emotional climax that takes place in the middle of a [[wormhole]] portal is represented by the stylized interior of a [[mandelbulb]].{{Cite web|url = http://blogs.indiewire.com/animationscoop/immersed-in-movies-going-into-the-big-hero-6-portal-20150130|title = Immersed in Movies: Going Into the 'Big Hero 6' Portal|date = January 30, 2015|accessdate = May 3, 2015|website = Animation Scoop|publisher = Indiewire|last = Desowitz|first = Bill}} The post-credits scene was only added to the film in August 2014, late in production, after co-director Don Hall and his crew went to see [[Marvel Studios]]' ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)|Guardians of the Galaxy]]''. He stated that "[i]t horrified us, that people were sat waiting for an end credits thing, because of the Marvel DNA. We didn't want people to leave the movie disappointed."{{cite web|last1=Brew|first1=Simon|title=Has the post-credits sting run its course?|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/movies/post-credits-scenes/35523/has-the-post-credits-sting-run-its-course|website=Den of Geek!|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing Limited]]|accessdate=May 28, 2015|date=May 27, 2015}} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Big Hero 6 (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Henry Jackman]] | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start Animation Studios]] | prev_title = [[Frozen (soundtrack)|Frozen]] | prev_year = 2013 | next_title = [[Zootopia#Music|Zootopia]] | next_year = 2016 | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[Henry Jackman]] | type = soundtrack | prev_title = [[Captain America: The Winter Soldier (soundtrack)|Captain America: The Winter Soldier]] | prev_year = 2014 | title = Big Hero 6 | year = 2014 | next_title = [[The Interview]] | next_year = 2014 }} {{Singles | name = Big Hero 6 (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) | type = soundtrack | single1 = [[Immortals (Fall Out Boy song)|Immortals]] | single1date = October 14, 2014 }} }} [[Henry Jackman]] composed the [[Film score|score for the film]].{{cite web|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/04/03/henry-jackman-to-score-disneys-big-hero-6|title=Henry Jackman to Score Disney's 'Big Hero 6'|publisher=Film Music Reporter|accessdate=April 3, 2014}} The soundtrack features an original song titled "[[Immortals (Fall Out Boy song)|Immortals]]" written and recorded by American rock band [[Fall Out Boy]], which was released by [[Walt Disney Records]] on October 14, 2014.{{cite web|last1=Wickman|first1=Kase|title='Big Hero 6' Sizzle Reel Brings New Fall Out Boy Song, Two Minutes of Cuteness|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1958868/big-her-6-sizzle-reel-fall-out-boy|publisher=MTV|accessdate=October 14, 2014|date=October 9, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Dornbush|first1=Jonathon|title=Hear 'Immortals,' Fall Out Boy's song from the 'Big Hero 6' soundtrack|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2014/10/14/big-hero-6-fall-out-boy-immortals|accessdate=October 14, 2014|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=October 14, 2014}} The soundtrack album was digitally released by Walt Disney Records on November 4, 2014, and had a CD release on November 24.{{cite news|title='Big Hero 6' Soundtrack Details|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/10/15/big-hero-6-soundtrack-details|accessdate=October 25, 2014|work=Film Music Reporter|date=October 15, 2014}} While not part of the soundtrack, a brief instrumental section of "[[Eye of the Tiger]]" plays in the film.{{cite news|last1=Feldman|first1=Abigail|title='Big Hero 6' succeeds at box office|url=http://tuftsdaily.com/arts/2014/11/12/big-hero-6-succeeds-box-office|accessdate=November 16, 2014|work=The Tufts Daily|date=November 12, 2014}} ===Track listing=== {{Track listing | total_length = 53:57 | all_music = [[Henry Jackman]] (except "[[Immortals (Fall Out Boy song)|Immortals]]", performed by [[Fall Out Boy]]) | headline = | extra_column = Artist | title1 = [[Immortals (song)|Immortals]] | extra1 = [[Fall Out Boy]] | writer1 = [[Patrick Stump]], [[Pete Wentz]], [[Joe Trohman]], [[Andy Hurley]] | length1 = 3:15 | title2 = Hiro Hamada | length2 = 1:57 | title3 = Nerd School | length3 = 2:12 | title4 = Microbots | length4 = 1:46 | title5 = Tadashi | length5 = 1:46 | title6 = Inflatable Friend | length6 = 1:56 | title7 = Huggable Detective | length7 = 1:35 | title8 = The Masked Man | length8 = 1:29 | title9 = One of the Family | length9 = 1:49 | title10 = Upgrades | length10 = 2:27 | title11 = The Streets of San Fransokyo | length11 = 4:08 | title12 = To the Manor Born | length12 = 1:15 | title13 = So Much More | length13 = 3:01 | title14 = First Flight | length14 = 2:35 | title15 = Silent Sparrow | length15 = 4:39 | title16 = Family Reunion | length16 = 2:39 | title17 = Big Hero 6 | length17 = 6:57 | title18 = I Am Satisfied with My Care | length18 = 5:29 | title19 = Signs of Life | length19 = 1:14 | title20 = Reboot | length20 = 1:48 }} ==Release== ''Big Hero 6'' [[Film premiere|premiered]] on October 23, 2014 as the opening film at the [[Tokyo International Film Festival]].{{cite web|last1=Amidi|first1=Amid|title=World Premieres of 'Big Hero 6' and 'Parasyte' Set for Tokyo International Film Festival|url=http://www.cartoonbrew.com/festivals/big-hero-6-world-premiere-tokyo-film-festival-102330.html|publisher=[[Cartoon Brew]]|accessdate=August 7, 2014|date=July 31, 2014}} The world premiere of ''Big Hero 6'' in 3D took place at the [[Abu Dhabi Film Festival]] on October 31, 2014.{{cite web|url =http://www.thenational.ae/arts-lifestyle/film/20141031/world-premiere-of-big-hero-6-in-3d-to-close-abu-dhabi-film-festival|title=World premiere of Big Hero 6 in 3D to close Abu Dhabi Film Festival|work=The National|date=October 31, 2014|accessdate=November 3, 2014}} It was theatrically released in the United States and Canada on November 7, 2014{{cite news|last1=Bahr|first1=Lindsey|title=Big Hero 6 Preview|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20483133_20847349,00.html|accessdate=September 14, 2014|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=August 24, 2014}} with limited [[IMAX]] international showings.{{cite web|url=https://www.imax.com/movies/m/big-hero-6-an-imax-3d-experience|title=Big Hero 6 An IMAX 3D Experience|work=IMAX.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022133701/https://www.imax.com/movies/m/big-hero-6-an-imax-3d-experience/|archivedate=October 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Theatrically, the film was accompanied by the Walt Disney Animation Studios short, ''[[Feast (2014 film)|Feast]]''.{{cite news|title=Walt Disney Animation Studios' 'Feast' to Premiere at the Annecy International Animated Film Festival|url=https://thewaltdisneycompany.com/blog/walt-disney-animation-studios-feast-premiere-annecy-international-animated-film-festival|accessdate=April 24, 2014|newspaper=Disney Post|date=April 24, 2014}} For the South Korean release of the film, it was retitled ''Big Hero'', to avoid the impression of being a sequel, and edited to remove indications of the characters' Japanese origin. This is owing to the [[Japan–South Korea relations|tense relations between Korea and Japan]]. For instance, the protagonist's name, Hiro Hamada, was changed to "Hero Armada", and Japanese-language signage onscreen was changed to English. Nonetheless, the film caused some online controversy in South Korea, because of small images resembling the [[Rising Sun Flag]] in the protagonist's room.{{cite news|last1=Ashcraft|first1=Brian|title=Why Big Hero 6 Is Upsetting Some People in South Korea|url=http://kotaku.com/why-big-hero-6-is-upsetting-some-people-in-south-korea-1680370861|accessdate=January 19, 2015|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=January 19, 2015}} The film was released in China on February 28, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/02/jupiter-ascending-spongebob-international-box-office-1201370333/|title='Jupiter' Ascends A Touch; 'Exodus' Crosses $200M: Intl Box Office Actuals|last=Tartaglione|first=Nancy|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=February 15, 2015}} ===Home media=== ''Big Hero 6'' was released in the United States by [[Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment]] on [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] and [[DVD]] on February 24, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Big-Hero-6-Blu-ray/110064/|title=Big Hero 6 Blu-ray|website=''Blu-ray.com''}}{{cite web|last=Gallagher|first=Brian|title='Big Hero 6' Is Coming to DVD and Blu-ray This February|url=http://www.movieweb.com/big-hero-6-movie-dvd-blu-ray-release-date|website=Movieweb|accessdate=January 6, 2015|date=January 6, 2015}} Writer [[Steven T. Seagle]], who co-created the comic book ''[[Big Hero 6 (comics)|Big Hero 6]]'', criticized the Blu-ray featurette documenting the origins of the group, for not mentioning him or co-creator [[Duncan Rouleau]]. Seagle also criticized the book ''Art of Big Hero 6'' for the same omission.Phegley, Kiel (March 12, 2015). [http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/man-of-action-on-big-hero-6-comicshollywood-relationship-credit-is-proper "Man of Action On "Big Hero 6" & Comics/Hollywood Relationship: 'Credit Is Proper'"]. Comic Book Resources. ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Big Hero 6'' earned $222.5 million in North America and $435.3 million in other territories for a worldwide estimated total of $657.8 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=disney2014.htm|title=Big Hero 6 (2014)|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]]|accessdate=May 29, 2015}} Calculating in all expenses, [[Deadline Hollywood|''Deadline'']] estimated that the film made a profit of $187.34 million.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/big-hero-6-profit-box-office-2014-1201390825/|title=No. 7 'Big Hero 6' – 2014 Most Valuable Blockbuster Movie Tournament|author=Mike Fleming Jr.|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 12, 2015|accessdate=March 13, 2015}} Worldwide, it is the highest-grossing animated film of 2014, the third-highest-grossing non-Pixar animated film from Disney,{{cite web | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2015/02/22/oscar-money-watch-big-hero-6-quietly-became-one-of-disneys-biggest-hits/|title=Oscar Money Watch: 'Big Hero 6' Quietly Became One Of Disney's Biggest Hits|author=Scott Mendelson | publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=February 23, 2015 | accessdate=February 24, 2015}} and the [[List of highest-grossing animated films|16th-highest-grossing animated film of all time]]. By grossing over $500 million worldwide, it became the fourth [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Disney]] release of [[2014 in film|2014]] to do so; the other titles being ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)|Guardians of the Galaxy]]'', ''[[Maleficent (film)|Maleficent]]'', and ''[[Captain America: The Winter Soldier]]''.{{cite web | url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=4019&p=.htm | title=Around-the-World Roundup: 'Jupiter' Ascends to Top Spot Overseas | publisher=IMDB | work=boxofficemojo.com | accessdate=February 9, 2015}} ====North America==== In the U.S. and Canada, the film is the second-highest-grossing science-fiction animated film (behind 2008's ''[[WALL-E]]''),{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/genres/chart/?id=scifianimation.htm | title = Animation – Sci-Fi | publisher = ''[[Box Office Mojo]]'' | accessdate = February 19, 2015}} the second-highest-grossing animated superhero comedy film (behind 2004's ''[[The Incredibles]]''),{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/genres/chart/?id=superherocomedy.htm | title = Superhero – Comedy | publisher = ''[[Box Office Mojo]]'' | accessdate = February 19, 2015}} and the second-highest-grossing Disney animated film (behind 2013's ''Frozen'').{{cite web | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/franchises/chart/?id=disneyanimation.htm | title = Walt Disney Animation Studios | publisher = ''[[Box Office Mojo]]'' | accessdate = February 19, 2015}} The film earned $1.4 million from late Thursday night showings, which is higher than the previews earned by ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]'' ($1.2 million) and ''[[The Lego Movie]]'' ($400,000).{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/11/interstellar-big-hero-6-box-office-1201274335/b|title='Interstellar' & 'Big Hero 6' Off To Strong Box Office Starts – Thursday B.O.|author=Anita Busch|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=November 7, 2014|accessdate=November 8, 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/11/07/box-office-interstellar-nabs-3-5m-thursday|title=Box Office: 'Interstellar' Nabs $3.5M Thursday, Has $4.9M Heading Into Weekend|author=Scott Mendelson|work=Forbes|date=November 7, 2014|accessdate=November 8, 2014}} In its opening day on November 7, the film earned $15.8 million, debuting at number two behind ''[[Interstellar (film)|Interstellar]]'' ($16.9 million).{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/interstellar-tops-friday-box-office-big-hero-6-weekend-win-1201351282|title='Interstellar' Tops Friday Box Office, 'Big Hero 6' Skyrocketing to Weekend Win of $56 Million|author=Maane Khatchatourian|publisher=''Variety''|date=November 8, 2014|accessdate=November 9, 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/11/08/box-office-interstellar-tops-big-hero-6-with-17m-friday|title=Box Office: 'Interstellar' Tops 'Big Hero 6' With $17M Friday|author=Scott Mendelson|publisher=''Forbes''|date=November 8, 2014|accessdate=November 9, 2014}} ''Big Hero 6'' topped the box office in its opening weekend, earning $56.2 million from 3,761 theaters ahead of ''Interstellar'' ($47.5 million);{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/box-office-big-hero-6-races-past-interstellar-with-56-2-million-1201351794|title=Box Office: 'Big Hero 6' Races Past 'Interstellar' With $56.2 Million|author=Brent Lang|publisher=''Variety''|date=November 9, 2014|accessdate=November 10, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://m.hollywoodreporter.com/entry/view/id/829229|title=Box Office: 'Big Hero 6' Wins With $56.2M; 'Interstellar' No. 2 With $50M|author=Pamela McClintock|publisher=''The Hollywood Reporter''|date=November 9, 2014|accessdate=November 10, 2014}} it is Walt Disney Animation Studios' second-best opening behind ''Frozen'' ($67.4 million), both adjusted and unadjusted.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/franchises/chart/?view=openings&id=disneyanimation.htm&p=.htm|title=Walt Disney Animation Studios – Opening Gross (2007 – present)|website=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=November 10, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/showdowns/chart/?view=weekend&id=disneyanimationnov.htm|title=November Disney Animation – Weekend Box Office|website=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=November 10, 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2014/11/09/box-office-big-hero-6-tops-interstellar-with-56-2m-weekend|title=Box Office: 'Big Hero 6' Tops 'Interstellar' With $56.2M Weekend|author=Scott Mendelson|publisher=''Forbes''|date=November 9, 2014|accessdate=November 10, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3956&p=.htm|title=Weekend Report: Disney's 'Big Hero 6' Eclipses Nolan's 'Interstellar'|author=Ray Subers|publisher=Box Office Mojo|date=November 9, 2014|accessdate=November 15, 2014}} On February 15, 2015, ''Big Hero 6'' became the third-highest-grossing Disney animated film in both the U.S. and Canada, behind ''[[The Lion King]]'' and ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/1844163/big-hero-6-is-now-disney-animations-third-most-successful-film-of-all-time|title=Box Office: 'Big Hero 6' Is Now Disney Animation's Third Most Successful Film Of All Time |date=February 15, 2015|accessdate=February 16, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/box-office-fifty-shades-of-grey-explodes-with-record-breaking-81-7-million-1201434486/|title=Box Office: 'Fifty Shades of Grey' Explodes With Record-Breaking $81.7 Million |author=Brent Lang|publisher=''Variety''|date=February 15, 2015|accessdate=February 16, 2015}} ====Outside North America==== Two weeks ahead of its North American release, ''Big Hero 6'' was released in Russia (earned $4.8 million) and Ukraine (earned $0.2 million) in two days (October 25–26).{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/10/international-box-office-fury-annabelle-hercules-happy-new-year-china-guardians-861602|title=Int'l Box Office: 'Annabelle' Still A Doll With $26.5M Frame; 'Fury' Wages $11.2M; 'Lucy' Outmuscles 'Hercules' In China; 'Guardians' Warps To #3 On 2014 Global Hit List; More|author=Nancy Tartaglione|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=October 26, 2014|accessdate=October 27, 2014}} The main reason behind the early release was in order to take advantage of the two weeks of school holidays in Russia. Jeff Bock, box office analyst for ''Exhibitor Relations'', said "For a two-day gross, that's huge. It's a giant number in Russia."{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/10/26/big-hero-6-russia/17959391|title='Big Hero 6' scores in Russia before U.S. release|author=Bryan Alexander|work=USA Today|date=October 27, 2014|accessdate=October 27, 2014}} In its second weekend, the film added $4.8 million (up 1%) bringing its total nine-day cumulative audience to $10.3 million in Russia and $10.9 including its revenue from Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/11/international-box-office-guardians-of-the-galaxy-number-2-movie-2014-turtles-china-maze-runner-kung-fu-jungle-happy-new-year-1201271064|title='Turtles', 'Maze Runner' Top Int'l Box Office; 'Guardians' Is 2014's #2 Pic: Update|author=Nancy Tartaglione|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=November 2, 2014|accessdate=November 3, 2014}} In its opening weekend, the film earned $7.6 million from seventeen markets for a first weekend worldwide total of $79.2 million, behind ''Interstellar'' ($132.2 million).{{cite web|url=http://m.hollywoodreporter.com/entry/view/id/826162|title=Global Box Office: Christopher Nolan's 'Interstellar' Rockets to $80M Overseas|author=Pamela McClintock|publisher=''The Hollywood Reporter''|date=November 9, 2014|accessdate=November 10, 2014}} It went to number one in the Philippines, Vietnam, and Indonesia. It opened with $4.8 million in Mexico.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/interstellar-box-office-300-million-globally-1201357910|title=Box Office: 'Interstellar' Soars Past $300 Million Globally|author=Brent Lang|publisher=''Variety''|date=November 16, 2014|accessdate=November 17, 2014}} In Japan, where the film is locally known as ''Baymax'', it opened at second place behind ''[[Yo-Kai Watch: Tanjō no Himitsu da Nyan!]]'', with $5.3 million, marking it the second-biggest [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Disney]] opening in Japan behind ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]''.{{cite web | url = http://deadline.com/2014/12/international-box-office-hobbit-five-armies-big-hero-6-pk-gone-with-the-bullets-results-1201332492/ | title = 'Hobbit' Rules While Chinese, Indian And French Films Make Noise: Intl BO Update | author = Nancy Tartaglione | publisher = Deadline.com | date = December 22, 2014 | accessdate = December 28, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Yo-kai Watch Film Beats Out Disney's Big Hero 6 at Japanese Box Office|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-12-22/yo-kai-watch-film-beats-out-disney-big-hero-6-at-japanese-box-office/.82528|website=Anime News Network|accessdate=January 18, 2015}} and topped the box office for six consecutive weekends.{{cite web | url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/japan-box-office-fifty-shades-773797 | title = Japan Box Office: 'Fifty Shades' Opens in Fifth, 'Big Hero 6' Passes $70 Million | author = Gavin J Blair | publisher =''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''|date=February 16, 2015|accessdate=February 19, 2015}} The film opened in second place with $6 million ($6.8 million including previews) in the U.K., which is 15% lower than ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]''.{{cite web | url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=4014&p=.htm | title=Around-the-World Roundup: 'Hobbit' Hits $900 Million Worldwide | publisher=IMDB | work=boxofficemojo.com | accessdate=February 2, 2015}} It opened at No. 1 with $14.8 million in China, which is the biggest opening for a Disney and Pixar animated film (breaking ''Frozen''{{'s}} record){{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/focus-fifty-shades-best-exotic-marigold-hotel-2-international-box-office-1201383936/|title=Mr Grey Dominates, Mr Smith's 'Focus' Pulls & Ms Smith's 'Exotic Marigold Hotel' Upgrades: More International Box Office|author=Nancy Tartaglione|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 1, 2015|accessdate=March 2, 2015}} and topped the box office for three consecutive weekends.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/china-box-office-big-hero-782414|title=China Box Office: 'Big Hero 6', 'Jupiter Ascending' Dominate|author=Clifford Coonan|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=March 16, 2015|accessdate=March 18, 2015}} The film became the highest-grossing Disney animated film in Vietnam and in China (surpassed by ''[[Zootopia]]''){{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-zootopia-roars-record-874827|title=Box Office: 'Zootopia' Roars to Record $25M Saturday in China, Nears $100M|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=March 12, 2016|accessdate=March 13, 2016}}), the second-highest-grossing Disney animated film of all time in Russia,{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/11/interstellars-80m-overseas-opening-is-alright-alright-alright-international-b-o-1201279558|title='Interstellar's $80M Overseas Opening Is Alright, Alright, Alright: International B.O.|author=Anthony D'Alessandro|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=November 9, 2014|accessdate=November 10, 2014}} in the Philippines (behind ''[[Toy Story 3]]''),{{cite web|url=http://m.hollywoodreporter.com/entry/view/id/826175|title=Global Box Office: 'Interstellar' Rockets Past $300M Worldwide|author=Pamela McClintock|publisher=''The Hollywood Reporter''|date=November 16, 2014|accessdate=November 17, 2014}} and in Japan (behind ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]''). In addition to being the second-highest-grossing Disney animated film, it is also the fifth-highest-grossing animated film of all time in China.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/international-box-office-insurgent-home-gunman-cinderella-kingsman-1201396540/|title='Insurgent' Tops Overseas Box Office; DWA's 'Home' Runs Up $19M – Update|author=Nancy Tartaglione|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 22, 2015|accessdate=March 23, 2015}} In total earnings, its biggest markets outside of the United States and Canada are China ($83.5 million) and Japan ($76 million).{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/05/disney-international-one-billion-box-office-avengers-ultron-cinderella-big-hero-6-1201420079/|title=Disney Crosses $1B at International Box Office; Propelled By 'Ultron', 'Cinderella'|author=Nancy Tartaglione|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=May 3, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} ===Critical response=== {{Anchor|Critics|Critical response}} The review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 89% of critics gave the film a positive review based on 211 reviews, with an average score of 7.3/10. The site's consensus states: "Agreeably entertaining and brilliantly animated, ''Big Hero 6'' is briskly-paced, action-packed, and often touching."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/big_hero_6|title=''Big Hero 6'' (2014)|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango Media]]|accessdate=November 22, 2018}} [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Normalization (statistics)|normalized]] rating out of 100 from top reviews from mainstream critics, calculated a score of 74 based on 38 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/big-hero-6|title=''Big Hero 6'' Reviews|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=December 16, 2014}} Michael O'Sullivan of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' gave the film 3.5/4 stars, writing that "The real appeal of ''Big Hero 6'' isn't its action. It's the central character's heart."{{cite web|author=Michael O'Sullivan|work=[[Washington Post]]|date= November 6, 2014|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/big-hero-6-movie-review-baymax-to-the-rescue/2014/11/05/18ca7d08-613c-11e4-91f7-5d89b5e8c251_story.html|title= Big Hero 6}} Maricar Estrella of ''Fort Worth Star-Telegram'' gave the film 5 stars, saying it "offers something for everyone: action, camaraderie, superheroes and villains. But mostly, Baymax offers a compassionate and healing voice for those suffering, and a hug that can be felt through the screen."{{cite web|author=Marcier Estrella|work=Fort Worth Star-Telegram|date=November 7, 2014|url=http://www.dfw.com/2014/11/06/941360/movie-review-big-hero-6.html|title=Big Hero 6}} [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave the film 3 out of 4 stars, stating, "The breakthrough star of the season is here. His name is Baymax and he's impossible not to love. The 3-D animated ''Big Hero 6'' would be a ton less fun without this irresistible blob of roly-poly, robot charisma."{{cite web|author=Peter Travers|author-link=Peter Travers|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=November 7, 2014|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/big-hero-6-20141107|title=Big Hero 6}} Kofi Outlaw of ''Screen Rant'' gave the film 4 out of 5 stars or "excellent", explaining that "''Big Hero 6'' combines Disney wonder and charm with Marvel awe and action to deliver a film that exhibits the best of both studios."{{cite web|author=Kofi Outlaw|work=Screen Rant|date=November 7, 2014|url=http://screenrant.com/big-hero-6-reviews-movie/|title= Big Hero 6}} [[Alonso Duralde]] of ''[[The Wrap]]'' gave the film a positive review, calling it "sweet and sharp and exciting and hilarious" and says that the film "comes to the rescue of what's become a dreaded movie trope—the origin story—and launches the superhero tale to pleasurable new heights."{{cite web|author=Alonso Duralde|work=[[The Wrap]]|date=October 23, 2014|url=http://www.thewrap.com/big-hero-6-review-disneys-superhero-epic-is-smart-translation-of-japanese-anime|title=Big Hero 6}} Calvin Wilson of ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'' gave the film 3.5 of 4 stars, writing that "the storytelling is solid, propelled by characters that you come to care about. And that should make ''Big Hero 6'' a big hit."{{cite web|author=Calvin Wilson|work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]|date=November 6, 2014|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/big-hero-should-thrill-kids-and-adults-alike/article_16d762e8-683a-5ec4-aeee-c6fe4f2835ae.html|title= Big Hero 6}} Bill Goodykoontz of ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' gave the film a positive review, writing, "Directors Don Hall and Chris Williams have made a terrific movie about a boy (Ryan Potter) and his robot friend, who seek answers to a deadly tragedy," calling it an "unexpectedly good treat".{{cite web|author=Bill Goodykoontz|work=[[The Arizona Republic]]|date=November 5, 2014|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/movies/2014/11/05/review-big-hero-unexpectedly-good-treat/18556833/|title=Big Hero 6}} Soren Anderson of ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' gave the film 3.5 out of 4 stars, saying that "Clever, colorful, fast on its feet, frequently very funny and sweet (but not excessively so), ''Big Hero 6'' mixes its myriad influences into a final product that, while in no way original, is immensely entertaining."{{cite web|author=Soren Anderson|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=November 6, 2014|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/entertainment/2024962465_bighero6xml.html|title=Big Hero 6|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218192448/http://seattletimes.com/html/entertainment/2024962465_bighero6xml.html|archivedate=December 18, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Michael Rechtshaffen of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying that "the funny and heartwarming story about the bond between a teen tech geek and a gentle robot represents another can't-miss proposition by Walt Disney Animation Studios."{{cite web|author=Michael Rechtshaffen|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 23, 2014|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/big-hero-6/review/742707|title=Big Hero 6}} Jon Niccum of ''[[The Kansas City Star]]'' gave the film 3.5 out of four stars, writing that while it "may hit a few familiar beats inherent to any superhero 'origin story,'" it is still "the best animated film of the year, supplying ''The Incredibles''-size adventure with a level of emotional bonding not seen since ''The Iron Giant''", and that it "never runs low on battery power".{{cite web|author=Jon Niccum|work=[[The Kansas City Star]]|date=November 6, 2014|url=http://www.kansascity.com/entertainment/movies-news-reviews/article3563223.html|title=Big Hero 6}} Elizabeth Weitzman of the ''[[New York Daily News|Daily News]]'' gave the film 4 out of 5 stars, calling it a "charming animated adventure", saying that with "appealing 3D animation" and a smart and "sharp story and script", it is "one of the rare family films that can fairly boast of having it all: humor, heart and huggability".{{cite web|author= Elizabeth Weitzman|work=The [[New York Daily News|Daily News]]|date=November 5, 2014|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/movies/big-hero-6-movie-review-article-1.2000683|title=Big Hero 6}} Rafer Guzmán from ''[[Newsday]]'' gave the film 3 out of 4 stars, saying that "Marvel plus Disney plus John Lasseter equals an enjoyable jumble of kid-approved action", with "rich, vivid colors and filled with clever details".{{cite web|author=Rafer Guzmán|work=News Day|date=November 7, 2014|url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/movies/big-hero-6-review-entertaining-and-kid-approved-1.9588029|title=Big Hero 6}} ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" width="95%" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | List of awards and nominations |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Award ! Category ! Recipients and nominees !
